title: حَبَّذَا وَلَا حَبَّذَا
description: Learn about حَبَّذَا and لَا حَبَّذَا, classical Arabic expressions for approval and disapproval, their grammatical parsing, and usage in eloquent speech.

notes.title: What is حَبَّذَا?
content: حَبَّذَا is a classical Arabic expression used to express strong approval or admiration, meaning 'how excellent!' or 'how wonderful!' It is composed of the verb حَبَّ (to love/approve) and the demonstrative ذَا (this).
This expression is considered one of أساليب المدح (expressions of praise) in Arabic grammar. It functions similarly to نِعْمَ but carries a more emphatic and emotional tone.
keyPoints: ذَا is always the فاعل (subject) of حَبَّ
The المخصوص بالمدح (praised noun) comes after

examples.english: How wonderful is generosity as a character trait!
How excellent is Zayd as a man!

notes.title: Grammatical Parsing of حَبَّذَا
content: In حَبَّذَا, the word حَبَّ is a past tense verb (فعل ماض جامد) that does not conjugate. The demonstrative ذَا serves as its subject (فاعل) and is always مبني (indeclinable).

The المخصوص بالمدح (the specified praised noun) that follows can be parsed in two ways: as a مبتدأ مؤخر (delayed subject) with حَبَّذَا being the خبر مقدم, or as a خبر لمبتدأ محذوف (predicate of an omitted subject).
keyPoints: حَبَّ: فعل ماض جامد مبني على الفتح
ذَا: اسم إشارة مبني في محل رفع فاعل
المخصوص بالمدح: مبتدأ مؤخر أو خبر لمبتدأ محذوف
The entire expression is جملة فعلية

examples.english: حَبَّ: فعل، ذَا: فاعل، الوَفَاءُ: مبتدأ مؤخر
How excellent is patience during calamity!
How praiseworthy is the seeker of knowledge!
How excellent you are as a friend!

notes.title: The Expression لَا حَبَّذَا
content: لَا حَبَّذَا is the negative counterpart of حَبَّذَا, expressing strong disapproval or condemnation. It means 'how bad!' or 'how blameworthy!' and is one of أساليب الذم (expressions of blame).
The grammatical structure remains the same, with لَا being حرف نفي (negation particle). This expression is particularly common in classical poetry and eloquent prose.
keyPoints: لَا is a negation particle (حرف نفي)

examples.english: How contemptible is stinginess as a trait!
How excellent is justice, and how blameworthy is injustice!

notes.title: Classical Usage and Poetry
content: حَبَّذَا and لَا حَبَّذَا appear frequently in classical Arabic poetry and prose. The Arabs used these expressions to add emotional weight and rhetorical beauty to their speech.
These expressions are still used in Modern Standard Arabic for eloquent and formal contexts, though they are less common in everyday speech.
keyPoints: Adds rhetorical beauty and emotional emphasis
The تمييز clarifies the aspect being praised or blamed

examples.english: Oh, how wonderful is the one who excuses me in love!
How wonderful a glance, and how wonderful a speaker!

examples.arabic: وَلَا حَبَّذَا مَنْ لَا يُوَفِّي بِوَعْدِهِ
examples.english: And how blameworthy is one who does not fulfill his promise!
How excellent is martyrdom in the path of Allah!
